Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down in thick, swirling sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my eyes darting between the icy road and the anxious passenger in the back seat. He kept checking his watch, muttering about missing his flight, and I felt the weight of his urgency pressing on me. My phone buzzed in the cup holder—my daughter’s name lit up the screen. I knew what it was about: tonight was the family dinner, the one where my grandson would finally announce his college acceptance. He’d asked me to be there, to hear the news with everyone else, to celebrate together. But here I was, crawling through traffic, responsible for getting this man to the airport safely and on time, even as the roads grew slicker and the minutes ticked by. My heart tugged me toward my family, toward laughter and hugs and pride. My duty as a driver demanded focus, patience, and care for the stranger in my back seat. I could feel the two worlds pulling me apart, each expecting all of me, and I didn’t know which way to turn.
